This seems to complicate this driver a bit (both code and ensuring that the code is tested) for probably little performance benefit.

Who handles LV activation in this case?  The iSCSI path calls activate_lv() but this new path does not.

What happens when c-vol and n-cpu are running in separate containers on the same host?  It's not guaranteed that the compute service can even access this device.

Do things like volume extend work as expected?

I'm not sure the tradeoffs are worthwhile here, especially given that most perf-sensitive deployments won't be using the LVM driver.  Is there any real-world usage info indicating that someone would really benefit from this?

cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py.message:
If changed to this, then the impact on other projects will be significant, requiring a large number of single tests
How much more performance does this change?

As I know ,this function only affects the attachments of lvm volumes in good way, it does not affect any actions such as migrating virtual machines across hosts or migrating volumes.

And because lvm-driver creates an single iscsi-target for each volume attachment. So, if there are multiple volumes attachment on one lvm cinder-volume, there will be multiple iscsi-targets, which will consume more CPU and memory resources that are not necessary.

If VM using the local path of lvm, the I/O path would go from  vm to the lv directly. In another way ,it will go from vm through iscsi-initiator, ethernet-card, to iscsi-target and then to lv.

So, it not only reduces resource consumption, but also improves some performance.
My doubts have been settled and I agree with your plan

swift/container/backend.py.message:
I think this statement cease to be true with the proposed change i.e. it is now possible for HEAD to return 404 while both _is_deleted and is_deleted return False

   HEAD -> get_info_is_deleted() -> get_info()
 
 vs
 
   is_deleted() -> _is_deleted()

Hmm, this part has me a little worried. If we go my commented approach, ie: It isn't deleted if there are objects, be them in the object table or shardranges. 

Basically because, even if we are sharded and we have objects in the object table, they're misplaced, but still objects. Then what about any objects that are in the wrong policy?

Surely, on the same vein we actually want to let the reconciler fix these objects first, if they're not deleted?

Maybe we need a:

  SELECT sum(object_count) as object_count FROM policy_stat

instead of the SQL below.

I like this approach as it's more targeted. But got me thinking about it last night. _get_alternate_object_stats here, when the db_state is SHARDED will return only the shardrange based stats. Which means there is a chance here in this code we never actually check the object table of the DB. 
Sure if it's sharded then we should look at the shards for object count, however, the object table in that case is used as a misplaced object location.. and so should also be considered objects (although misplaced) in this container.

So I think we can simplify this even more by simply removing this line. That way, info will contain the object_count from the internal object table. We then just need to include any shard object counts.

In fact, as this is just gathering info for _is_deleted_info, that is does it have any objects, can we get away with something even simpler and just sum them up?

  info = conn.execute('''
      SELECT put_timestamp, delete_timestamp, object_count
      FROM container_stat''').fetchone()
  info = dict(info)
  for key, value in self.get_shard_usage().items():
      if value:
          info[key] += value
  return self._is_deleted_info(**info)
  
Because even if there are no shards, we'll still get `sum([])` or 0's back. And whatever state we're in, if there are shards with objects, we probably don't want to be deleted so the sharder can do it's work to remidy the situation.
is the following actually restricted to that special case? curious that the conditions does not include get_db_state() == UNSHARDED

On reflection, I think we actually need to also consider get_shard_usage() while the db state is SHARDING, because once we fix the immediate bug stopping empty db's from sharding, those DBs will go to SHARDING but still be empty (i.e. no object rows in the DB) - but we do not want the DB to appear deleted during that time either!

I think that this test test.unit.container.test_backend.TestContainerBroker.test_is_deleted ought to need updating given this change. I suspect it still passes because the test broker has not been given an own_shard_range, but that isn't realistic: if a broker has shard ranges that have useful object_count then it would also have an own_sr.

Or, is there ever a case where we think get_shard_usage would return non-zero object count but that should be ignored? (NB get_shard_usage only sums shards with state in (ShardRange.ACTIVE, ShardRange.SHARDING, ShardRange.SHRINKING)

You shouldn't have to parse all of these options yourself here, keystoneauth provides a loading interface to do it for you: https://docs.openstack.org/keystoneauth/latest/api/keystoneauth1.loading.html#module-keystoneauth1.loading

I see there is two ways of doing this, either using the loading module or using the session module as I did. I saw more occurrences in other clients of the session module usage and feels a bit more readable. Anything against this practice? I didn't see many examples of loading.
You shouldn't need to do all this, the keystoneauth Adapter or LegacyJsonAdapter should be able to figure out the endpoint for you.
By looking at the code, it seems it doesn't resolve it itself. We need to explicitly pass it in order to get the proper endpoint.
This was some v2 voodoo - keystone v2 is gone now, you can remove this..

Let's replace this with a keystonev3 equivalent:

 
 from keystoneauth1.identity import v3
 from keystoneauth1 import session as ks
 from manilaclient import client

 auth_params  = {
  'auth_url' : OS_AUTH_URL,
  'username' : OS_USERNAME,
  'password' : OS_PASSWORD,
  'project_name' : OS_PROJECT_NAME,
  'project_domain_name' : OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME,
  'project_domain_id' : OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID,
  'user_domain_name' : OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME,
  'user_domain_id' : OS_USER_DOMAIN_ID,
 }

 authv3 = v3.Password(**auth_params)
 session = ks.Session(auth=authv3)
 manila = client.Client(client_version='2', session=session)
Moving this code (lines 56-199) into the http_client module will allow reuse and keep this file clean
we could clean these up now
Can't deprecate from a previous version - the latest released version is 2.4.0, so this should either be 2.5.0 or 3.0.0 depending on whether this change deserves a major version bump
Can we deprecate this one? "project_id" replaces this, and "project_name" is unique, so callers can use that too instead
we can remove this from here.
we can remove this from here

These three options are only relevant to keystoneclient - no need to carry them forward when we stop using keystoneclient. lets deprecate them - i.e., call out that they're not even used, like the removal on line 235 - we can drop it in a future release
this was deprecated a while ago, lets remove it
we can drop support for share_service_name

Want to ask if we really need this?
the session client can handle endpoint override and auth-token and this is an internal detail - if the user doesn't want to use a keystone session auth object, we can internally fetch one and return a session client anyway?

I think cinder has preserved their http client because they support interacting with the service in a standalone manner (i.e., when the service is using noauth) - we must check.
We've never supported the use of python-manilaclient sdk with noauth - to do that, we may need a way to fake out all this keystone interaction, like cinder's doing. 

So i don't mind us keeping the HTTPClient around to figure out the noauth piece; but, we should default to the SessionClient since that's what most users will use manila with keystone.

Tested locally and works fine. I'd still like a review from someone familiar with the RPC code.
Is it possible for you to add load also? Would be good to have feedback of it, as in CI in openstack we have no option for such tests

We used to have regular AMQP connection drops due to unprocessed heartbeats in both production and even completely empty testing environments, which turned out to be related to the problem this patch solves. So far we have confirmed that connection drops are gone completely in the lab environment, and dynamic routing functionality is not affected. We didn't test this patch under heavy load in production yet.

We need no load at all to spot the issue - 3 neutron controllers, 2 nodes with DrAgent, one BGP peering configured on each, and everything is 100% idle. RabbitMQ connection drops will already appear in logs. If the load that you wanted to see is the load that we run with the patch applied, it is not so high too - again 3 neutron controllers, 2 nodes with DrAgents, 2 BGP peers, ~200 prefixes advertised, stable network with not so much changes per minute.

nova/volume/cinder.py.message: (later) I just realized this is how we mean to raise nova exceptions instead of cinderclient ones ... but currently translate_attachment_exception only translates cinder_exception.NotFound.

I note that while this is a change in behavior, we generally use the pattern of not treating NotFound as a failure during a detach or delete operation. I think this is an improvement that makes attachment_delete more consistent with similar delete $thing code in the codebase and it also makes this call idempotent.

I also note that logging at level warning is consistent with how 409 (already activated) is treated for port binding activation in nova/network/neutron.py:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/93a65f06df67ce39d65827692150c78013c7f6d5/nova/network/neutron.py#L3168-L3172
This should really be raising a nova exception IMHO and not letting a cinderclient exception propagate up but that is out of scope and unrelated to this fix.

doc/source/install/verify.rst.message: Would it make more sense to do md5sum?

Do you want me to just add a comment to the previous step about running md5sum on the image file and comparing it to the api response? Just trying to figure out the best flow for adding that and the download diff.

I'd suggest adding a note or another paragraph after line 114, something like:

If the diff returns an error, take an md5 of the original image and compare it to the 'checksum' property of the get-image response.  If those differ, then the problem occurred during upload, and the data Glance stored is not correct.  In that case, you'll have to delete the image and create a new one.  If the value of the 'checksum' property is correct, then the data was somehow corrupted during the download.  Try downloading the image data again.

It may be worth mentioning the md5sum as well, because other image consumers (who don't have access to the original image) will have to rely on the 'checksum' property of the image record in order to verify downloads, so if the value of 'checksum' differs from the actual md5 of the image, then there's going to be trouble.

I thought about doing a checksum here, but decided it was more foolproof to just do the complete diff. If you did a checksum command instead of diff you'd have to manually compare the strings to make sure they're not the same. Sometimes that's easy, sometimes it's not. The advantage of diff here is that it will return 1 and explicitly say A is not B when they are different.
for the glanceclient, you have to use the image ID here

After your rebase, I think this should be:

cirros-0.4.0-x86_64-disk.img

In the time since I made this suggestion in 2017, I believe that the 'checksum' property is no longer populated, and will only be present on legacy images.  You'll have to explain how to use the 'os_hash_algo' and 'os_hash_value' image properties.  Probably just say something like:

If the diff returns an error, take a sha512sum of the original image and compare it to the 'os_hash_value' property displayed in the image-show response.  (If the 'os_hash_algo' property is something other than 'sha512', then you'll need to use the appropriate command to generate the value locally.)  If those differ, then the problem occurred during upload, and the data Glance stored is not correct.  In that case, you'll have to delete the image and create a new one.

(The glancelient, unlike osc, does download validation, so it shouldn't be possible for the download to succeed with an incorrect checksum.)

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think we need to update the commit message

Most specifically I think we want this change to highlight the fix in the replicator to be more robust in the face of ENODATA when doing clean-up (so that we can drain nodes with failing disks)

This commit message, oh as Clay mentioned needs to be updated. It isn't clear on what it does and what it effects.
E,g, oh this patch effects all the replicators and auditors? nope just the object ones. Maybe we should change it to something like (this of off the top of my head without looking at the code too much yet):

 Make the object replicator and auditor more robust to ENODATA
 
 Currently when the replicator or auditor hits an ENODATA corruption we bail.
 This patch will allow them to skip and continue in an effort to make progress on the work that needs to be done.

What about the rest of the commit message? how are you making it more robust? Doesn't have to be super detailed but unless it's a very obvious from the first line, we provide more details.
Usually we want to cover the "what's the issue", and "how it's been solved". See: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Summary_of_Git_commit_message_structure

It's why I also suggested a body of the commit message in my previous comment:

  Currently when the replicator or auditor hits an ENODATA corruption we bail.
  This patch will allow them to skip and continue in an effort to make progress on the work that needs to be done.
recommended word wrap on commit messages is 72 chars

these tests are helping me get a picture of where we need to be thinking about ENODATA

AFAIK, currently the only place we handle it "correctly" is hash_suffix_dir https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/832738

I think we can "ingore" ENODATA in *most* places the same way we ignore ENOTDIR - but we're going to need at least ONE place where we actually quarantine it.  I'm not sure if that one place should be in suffix rehashing, it seems like maybe the db/object audit location generators might be a reasonable target.  Can you add an ENODATA test for the object audit location generator?

glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
My opinion that this patch is useless, because it covers impossible things.

I'll try to explain what I mean. "marker" is an Image object, and when we sort by some field, "disk_format" for instance, there could be a situation when the value is not set for the marker object, i.e. "marker.disk_format is None".
Right now the code considers such situations and converts None to '', which is right.

This patch assumes situations when user wants to sort by non-existing field, i.e. "marker.NONEXISTING". In this case gettattr will return the default value, which will be converted to '' on the next line.

Why this is wrong:

1. User can't sort by non-existing fields, it's checked in api https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v2/images.py#L385-L387
And glance will return 400 long before the execution reaches this point. That's why applying the default value here makes no sense.

2. Even if execution reaches this point and it will be converted from None to '', sqlalchemy will fail later, because it can't sort by nonexisting field. And Glance will return 500 anyway.

I hope I put my though clearly. If there any questions I'm glad to discuss them.
Thanks for the detailed analysis Mike! Happy to stand by you on this one.

manila/policies/share_network.py.message:
Yeah, this non-scoped policy will need to be introduced as deprecated... weird, i know.. read on:

I know its a bit strange, but, the intent of all these current deprecations is so that we can make a transition into using the "scope" attribute exposed by keystone... in short - keystone now has a way for a user holding a particular role to operate at system scope or within a project's scope. 

Unfortunately, the use of scope is going to be a pretty major change to deployers, so, we want to ease the transition... and we want to make a coordinated transition across all openstack projects. The current plan is to stop supported these deprecated policies likely in the "A" or "B" releases. So, until then, every policy we introduce will need to have two parts:

1) Scoped policy like the one you've added on line 292 of this file
and
2) an un-scoped policy (where there's no "scope_types" argument") that is introduced as deprecated.

Hi Douglas, I talked with Carlos about it some time ago, and he said probably it's not necessary since it's a new API and doesn't exist when the deprecation happened at W release. If I understood wrong let me know, and we will fix in a follow-up patch.

this fails a bunch of times during testing the container driver: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/22d234d01d6740b6abe3b6c8d3f1a9cd/log/controller/logs/screen-m-shr.txt#10804-10926
is there any chance of this being none?

During migration script, we only add to subnets to map table when the share server has "share_network_subnet_id" field set. The subnet id on ShareServers model was "nullable=True", so there is a possibility to have a share server without subnet from previous environment (at least from the database design perspective). 

It's more a kind of defensive code. The "ShareServers" table does not block ShareServer to have empty "share_network_subnet_id". So, we prefer checking it before accessing the list first element. 

In new environments, I cannot see the possibility to be None. However, in upgrade pre-existent system, there is a possibility (very small, I think).


Finally, we don't know the future. The share network subnet can be changed for some reason, causing an exception here. Or even the db can be manually changed for some reason. The approach is: better to be safe, check if the list contains elements, before accessing it.


I don't have strong opnion here. I'm totally okay to change it to get directly the first element without any check, though.

WDYT ?

would setting the share network status to error be something interesting for us as well?
I'm thinking of that as a possible way to signalize that manila tried to add the subnet but failed

Yeah.. that's a possibility.. We have designed the feature in the spec to leave the share network back to active state, no matter failed or not. It follows the same pattern of update security service (failed operation will have network to active only share servers to error). 

Particularly, I'm okay with both. Just follow what we've decided during spec.

                                                      testcase_instance=self,
                                                      name='type01').id
        else:
            volume_type_id = None

        backup = utils.create_backup(self.context, size=5,
                                     testcase_instance=self,
                                     status=fields.BackupStatus.AVAILABLE,
                                     availability_zone='az1',
                                     host='testhost',
                                     volume_type_id=volume_type_id)

Also note it includes the "testcase_instance=self" keyword, which I think helps people reading the code. Otherwise, the "self" argument on L1545 looks mysterious.

Yes, this is correct. You need to explicitly delete these DB entries *before* the volume_type DB entry can be deleted by the cleanup code. The volume and backup objects must be deleted first, or else the cleanup code would fail when it tries to delete the volume_type.

cinder/service.py.message: You could add "-> None" for the return type. I don't see this done in other cinder class __init__(), so I'm not sure if that's an oversight or if you have a reason for not annotating the return.

mypy assumes that the return type for __init__ is None, so I've generally skipped adding it.  You can see that this works by adding a return here and running the mypy checks.  It will fail with something like

cinder/service.py:220:9: error: No return value expected  [return-value]
Ack, makes sense. And since I sometimes question S/N of some annotations (adds noise for not a lot of value), then I'm in favor of *not* adding "-> None" now that I know this is mypy implicit.

I'm still learning how mypy works, and am not sure what this change will do. I can imagine code in the manager that ensures the availability_zone is a str, so is this just asking mypy to cross-check to ensure the manager did it correctly?
This is another instance of me still learning mypy. Does it retain context across the entire file, and will use this annotation when it encounters L224?
Yup, that's what I was thinking. We're adding mypy annotation to counteract code that could be better written.

Correct, it sets the type information.

But, this is probably not the best way to do this.  Well-written python code would define self.model_disconnected as a member variable in __init__ and give it a value...

Taken on its own, this seems reasonable. I'm a little concerned the cinder code could get unwieldy if we end up annotating every local variable, especially when the variable's scope is noticeably small.

Typically, this would have been added here because line 287 implies a type of int, and then line 289 fails because it implies a conflicting type of Optional[int].

Doing this allows both cases.  But, running this now w/o line 285 doesn't seem to generate that error... unclear why.
Needs Optional[] now that we have enabled no_implicit_optional.
Per my previous observation, this is another place where "-> None" could be added (though I don't see a lot of value).
Nevermind, just adds noise as it's implicit.

I know it's a slippery slope, but none of these are annotated. Again, though, I don't see a lot of value in plastering the code with annotations that don't add real value, so I'm OK leaving this class alone for now.

zuul/connection/__init__.py.message: Not a minus one, but I think a reasonable thing to consider: I think this is the only place we actually use LookupError.  We could simplify a bunch of calling sites by adding in a "want_exceptions" argument, false by default, true here.

I think that makes sense. I solved it a bit differently by introducing a `default` argument to be returned in case of a cache miss. This way I can keep raising the LookupError by default.

I felt that was the least surprising behavior. Not raising by default conflates the cache miss and error case, so I wanted to make that a bit more explicit.

If you have a strong opinion on the default behavior I'm open to changing that the way you suggested.
Nit: You should be able to set the default to [] here and then drop the block on lines 318-319.
I think that wouldn't work as branches can still be None in the error case. The default is only returned when there is a cache miss.
Oh right. None is the default and the error value. Only the default would change by setting it to [] but the error value could be None.

zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py.message:
Don't we need to catch the LookupError here too? Or does raising an error properly finish the processing necessary here? It seems that the newly_protected and newly_unprotected values would be wrong if old_proected_branches is an empty set due to the LookupError as well. Maybe we should raise early if we just want to stop processing.

Seperately do we need to handle the case where we attempt set(None) which is a TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable?

I think the key thing to note about updateProjectBranches is that it doesn't want to perform more queries than necessary.  In particular, we don't want it to look up unprotected branches if there are no tenants that use unprotected branches.  That's why it checks to see if there is a cache entry for each of the two forks and only runs that query if there is.

If one of the forks is null, it doesn't have the information needed to know whether that query is necessary or not (the exclude_unprotected argument to getProjectBranches supplies that information in that case, so it knows whether it should perform a query).

Yep, we need to deal with the set(None) case.

I think it makes sense to restructure this method a bit and abort the event processing early. When the branch cache is empty (LookupError) or there was an error (None) it doesn't make sense to continue as `updateProjectBranches()` only updates when there are existing branches.

It also looks like we don't have to deal with None/LookupError for the "new protected branches" case, as we know that the cache is not empty and a fetch error in `updateProjectBranches()` would raise an exception and abort the event processing.

What I'm not sure is if the logic behind `updateProjectBranches()` is correct. I'd expect it to try and correct the branch cache when there was a fetch error or even populate the branch cache if empty. But I think I might be missing something about the life cycle of the branch cache.

zuul/zk/branch_cache.py.message:
I'm having trouble following that logic.  You say "if protected_branches is None we'll return None", but if remainder_branches in not None, then we can return something other than None even if protected branches is None.  Am I missing something?

(Basically: run through this code with: exclude_unprotected=True; protected_branches=None; remainder_branches=['master'];)
That update looks equivalent to me.

The remaining branches handling is in an else block to the if exclude_unprotected: condition. That means the block here is exclusive to processing remaining branches.

if exclude_unprotected == True then we skip over the else block when protected_branches is None and return None at the end of the method. I think we can simplify that by just checking if we need to handle remaining branches else return None.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm not sure I follow. From what I can see, some of the old rspec code would do things like this:

      let :params do
        default_params.merge({:some_param => 'some_value' })
      end
      
Which would result in a large set of params, based largely only the default_params values but with one param's value being overridden. Then the rspec code would test for the override.

The new code would look like this:

      let :params do
        {:some_param => 'some_value' }
      end

Resulting in a small set of params that still override the same set of default values.

Certainly the new code looks cleaner, but I guess I don't see where the old code wasn't testing default values.

I think I didn't explain it well. How is the updated version of the commit message ?

My point is that setting some parameters by the actual parameters is quite redundant and we can just let the class to use its own default. Unless we have any specific reason to do so, I prefer setting less parameters to makes sure none of the other parameters are affecting what is being tested.

This patch only makes sense if the plan is to enhance puppet-glance so that it has native support for configuring the paste-ini file's location. 

Otherwise, we're swapping one less then ideal solution (explicitly configuring the file location, but using glance::config::api_config hiera data) for another less than ideal solution (relying on glance to "find" the file).

This feels like a lateral move, requiring 3 steps to get back to where we are now:

1. This THT patch in order to avoid using glance::config::api_config hiera
2. A puppet-glance patch to add native support for configuring the paste-ini location
3. Another THT patch, replacing this one, to use the new facility implemented in step 2.
Just to clarify my position, I don't feel this is a wasted effort, nor do I wish to block puppet-glance work. I merely observe there are tradeoffs.

I still do not agree that this is waste of the maintenance effort. IMO we should not block any work in puppet-glance because of our usage in TripleO. If we keep using puppet then we should follow their best practice (use native parameters instead of using arbitrary config injection).

I would not intend to backport that change here but I believe it's still worth implementing in master.
I am all in favor of reducing the need for difficult maintenance work. Please just balance that against the maintenance effort that involves 3 patches in 2 projects :-/
I'll work on adding the parameter support for Glance. My initial motivation was to get rid of any direct injection as these makes our maintenance quite hard but I agree with what you wrote.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: The change itself seems fine, but do we actually use this "defaultbackend" image?  The discussion at https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/issues/8141 and the fact that it's disabled by default (https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/7806159b386bf34b3ef0d8f130e66ad0247903af/charts/ingress-nginx/values.yaml#L765) makes me wonder if it's actually needed still.

Yes, to use defaultbackend feature, users need to perform a helm-override to enable it.

My understanding is that we need to download this image at this stage, to support air tight environments where users may wish to enable the feature at a later stage.

That allows us to keep consistent with the upstream helm chart, where values.yaml documents the override and stx users may try to use it.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The merge commits is the reason we don't wait for an expected sha, just for the sha to be different than it was before the merge started.

Not sure I follow your second paragraph -- but the idea in that method is we wait for like 5 minutes for the branch tip to be different.  But we also don't call that method if the change doesn't show as being merged in Gerrit.

So if we have a 2 change bundle, then we:
1) Store the branch ref for all changes in the bundle

2) Submit change 1
3) Check that Gerrit says change 1 is merged
4) Check that the branch ref is different from what we saved in #1

5) Submit change 2 (it will return a 409 conflict error because it's already merged, but that's okay)
6) Check that Gerrit says change 2 is merged (it is)
7) Check tat the branch ref is different from what we saved in #1

Now, having written all that, I see that we're not storing everything in step 1, so I'm going to update this with a new revision.

Would it be more correct to set _ref_sha for change2 to the sha for change1? I suppose that presents the problem of needing to understand the tree relationship between changes within a project branch? Might also be inaccurate if there are intermediate merge commits?

Mostly looking at _waitForRefSha() and it seems we could wait an insufficient amount of time if one but not all of the changes in the bundle merge.

What i am trying to point here is that the sys.modules already created when we reach to the code with updating the module name as i understand , so it has a reference id . and i guess that  some code import the module py he has a reference to it. globals() and sys.modules should have the same id. now we come and change the sys.module file to orher location , means new id. is it possible that we have code for the same module which points to old sys.module id ???

Example:
During the run we have a full view of the resources sys.modules with full view , each module with its own id .

Now we should be aware to the risk of someone reffering (import) from current module in other places in the code.

and our code comes in and change the sys,modules[xxx] id to new one ... means we may have cached info that its not updated.

Example for POC:

import sys
print(f"Before: sys {id(sys.modules['math'])}")
import math
print(f"Before global: {id(globals()['math'])}")
sys.modules['math'] = "DDDD"
print(f"After: sys {id(sys.modules['math'])}")
print(f"After global: {id(globals()['math'])}")
